CCLI Landscape Analysis
South Florida Psalter Strategic Plan
Prepared by: Josiah Crane, Church Adoption Strategist
Date: February 7, 2026
Project: South Florida Psalter (Pray150 Psalter)

Executive Summary
The Christian Copyright Licensing International (CCLI) ecosystem represents the single most important distribution channel for congregational worship music in the English-speaking world. With 230,000+ churches licensed globally and a repertoire of 600,000+ songs, CCLI is not simply a licensing organization‚Äîit is the discovery engine that drives what churches sing on Sunday mornings.
For the South Florida Psalter (SFP) project to achieve widespread adoption across 150 Psalm settings, CCLI registration is not optional‚Äîit is foundational. However, the research reveals a sobering reality: the CCLI Top 100 is dominated by a handful of major publishers (Integrity Music, Hillsong, Bethel Music, Elevation Worship) and established worship brands. Independent artists rarely break through without significant grassroots momentum.
The opportunity: The Psalter movement is uniquely positioned to succeed where individual independent songs fail. We are not launching 150 separate songs; we are launching a liturgical framework, a discipleship tool, and a year-long worship curriculum. This changes everything.
The strategy: Build a movement before we chase charts. CCLI rankings are a lagging indicator of church adoption‚Äîthey reflect what churches are already singing, not what they should sing next. Our path to CCLI influence runs through pastors, worship leaders, and organic church adoption, not through marketing campaigns.

I. How CCLI Works: Registration, Reporting, and Chart Rankings
A. The CCLI Licensing Model
What CCLI Provides:

Church Copyright License (CCL): Allows churches to legally reproduce song lyrics for worship (print, projection, streaming)
SongSelect: Subscription service providing access to lyrics, chord charts, lead sheets, and vocal arrangements
Reporting Infrastructure: Churches report songs used; data aggregates into CCLI Top 100 charts
Royalty Distribution: License fees are distributed to publishers and songwriters based on usage reporting

Pricing Structure (U.S., 2026):

Churches under 25 people: $59/year
Churches 200,000+: $5,266/year
Majority of fees distributed as royalties to copyright owners

Critical Insight: CCLI is a pay-to-play ecosystem, but not in the traditional sense. You don‚Äôt pay for chart placement‚Äîyou earn it through actual church usage. The barrier to entry is registration; the barrier to success is adoption.
B. How Songs Climb the CCLI Charts
The Reporting Mechanism:

Churches with CCLI licenses report songs used in services (via Planning Center, ProPresenter, or manual entry)
CCLI aggregates usage data across all reporting churches
Songs are ranked by frequency of use (not by number of churches, but by total usage instances)
The CCLI Top 100 updates monthly, reflecting what churches sang in the previous reporting period

Key Factors Influencing Chart Position:

Volume of reporting churches: More churches = more data points
Consistency of use: Songs sung weekly vs. occasionally
Multi-generational appeal: Songs that work for both contemporary and traditional services
Ease of musicianship: Songs that mid-sized churches can execute (not just megachurches)
Theological depth + emotional accessibility: Head and heart together

What Does NOT Influence Rankings:

Spotify streams or YouTube views
Marketing spend or social media buzz
Label backing (though major labels have distribution advantages)
Artist celebrity or touring schedule

Insight for SFP: CCLI is a liturgical adoption metric, not a popularity contest. A song that 500 churches sing every week for a year will outperform a viral hit that 5,000 churches sing once. Consistency beats virality in the CCLI ecosystem.

II. Current CCLI Landscape Assessment (2026)
A. The CCLI Top 25-50: Who Dominates?
Based on available data, the CCLI Top 100 is dominated by:
Major Contemporary Worship Brands:

Hillsong Worship / UNITED (Australia): ‚ÄúOceans,‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat A Beautiful Name‚Äù
Bethel Music (Redding, CA): ‚ÄúGoodness of God,‚Äù ‚ÄúBuild My Life‚Äù
Elevation Worship (Charlotte, NC): ‚ÄúPraise,‚Äù ‚ÄúO Come to the Altar‚Äù
Chris Tomlin / Passion (Atlanta, GA): ‚ÄúHoly Forever,‚Äù ‚Äú10,000 Reasons‚Äù
CityAlight (Australia): Modern hymn-style worship

Recurring Themes:

Anthemic choruses: Sing-along melodies with simple, repeated phrases
Vertical focus: God-centered lyrics (not horizontal/community-focused)
Emotional accessibility: Songs that feel personal and intimate
Moderate tempo: 70-90 BPM range (slow enough for reflection, energetic enough for engagement)
Multi-generational appeal: Works for both boomers and Gen Z

Notable Observations:

Older songs persist: ‚Äú10,000 Reasons‚Äù (2011), ‚ÄúOceans‚Äù (2013), ‚ÄúGoodness of God‚Äù (2018) remain in rotation years after release
Label consolidation: Capitol CMG, Integrity Music, and Bethel Music collectively represent 60-70% of the Top 100
Repetition is rewarded: Songs with simple, memorable hooks outperform complex, lyric-dense compositions

B. The Independent Artist Gap
Critical Finding: Very few independent artists break into the CCLI Top 100 without institutional backing.
Why Independent Artists Struggle:

Discovery barrier: Churches find new songs through conferences, radio, and curated playlists‚Äîall controlled by major labels
Resource gap: Major labels provide chord charts, multitracks, training videos, and marketing
Trust deficit: Worship leaders hesitate to introduce unfamiliar artists to their congregations
Network effects: Once a song gains momentum, it becomes self-perpetuating (churches sing what other churches sing)

Exceptions to the Rule:

Sovereign Grace Music: Independent collective with theological credibility (Reformed/conservative evangelical churches)
Shane & Shane / The Worship Initiative: Musician-led, high-quality resources for worship leaders
CityAlight: Started small, grew through theological depth and musicality

Common Thread: Independent successes are movement-based, not artist-based. They represent theological communities, liturgical traditions, or musician collectives‚Äînot solo careers.
C. The Psalter Landscape: Who Else Is Setting Psalms to Music?
Major Competitors:


Keith & Kristyn Getty (Getty Music)

Modern hymn writers with strong Reformed/liturgical following
Focus: Congregational singability, theological depth, family worship
CCLI Presence: Multiple songs in Top 100 (though not primarily Psalm settings)
Strength: Conferences, choral arrangements, publishing infrastructure



Shane & Shane (The Worship Initiative / Psalms project)

Musician-focused resources (multitracks, tutorials, chord charts)
Focus: Equipping worship leaders, not just providing songs
CCLI Presence: Moderate (not Top 100, but well-known in evangelical circles)
Strength: Quality over quantity, musician respect



The Psalms Project (Shane Heilman)

Setting all 150 Psalms in their entirety (not excerpts)
Focus: Artistic, cinematic, narrative-driven arrangements
CCLI Presence: Minimal (designed for listening, not congregational singing)
Strength: Completeness, artistic integrity, storytelling



Sovereign Grace Music / Hymns of Grace / Psalms of Grace

Theologically conservative, Reformed tradition
Focus: Psalm singing as discipleship and liturgical formation
CCLI Presence: Strong within Reformed churches, limited outside
Strength: Denominational buy-in, theological credibility



Red Mountain Music / Matt Boswell & Matt Papa

Hymn-based worship, Psalm adaptations
Focus: Theological precision, poetic beauty
CCLI Presence: Growing (especially in conservative evangelical churches)
Strength: Pastoral endorsements, theological depth



The SFP Opportunity:

No one has successfully built a CCLI-friendly, church-adoptable, 150-Psalm congregational resource.
Most Psalter projects are either:

Too artistic for congregational use (Psalms Project)
Too niche for broad adoption (Sovereign Grace)
Incomplete (most projects cover 20-40 Psalms, not all 150)



The gap: A liturgically structured, theologically rich, musically accessible, church-ready Psalter that equips congregations to sing the entire Psalter over a year.

III. Church Adoption Patterns: How Worship Leaders Discover & Choose Songs
A. The Song Discovery Funnel
Based on research into worship leader behavior, song discovery follows a predictable pattern:
1. Exposure (How They Hear It)

Worship conferences: Passion, Getty Worship Conference, Worship Leader Institute
Church networks: Denominational gatherings, pastoral conferences
Peer recommendations: Other worship leaders in their city/network
Radio/streaming: K-LOVE, Air1, Spotify worship playlists
Social media: Instagram, YouTube tutorials, TikTok trends

2. Evaluation (How They Test It)

Theological soundness: Does it align with our church‚Äôs doctrine?
Congregational singability: Can our people learn and sing this?
Musicianship requirements: Can our team execute this?
Emotional resonance: Does it connect with our worship culture?
Flexibility: Does it work for different service styles?

3. Trial (How They Introduce It)

Small groups first: Test with youth group, prayer meeting, or small gathering
Repeat exposure: Introduce 2-3 times before expecting congregation to sing along
Provide resources: Print lyrics, play YouTube tutorials, send links ahead of time
Build momentum: If it works, cycle it into rotation every 4-6 weeks

4. Adoption (How It Becomes Part of the Repertoire)

Congregational ownership: People request it, sing it outside church
Liturgical fit: It becomes associated with specific moments (communion, benediction, call to worship)
Seasonal anchoring: Christmas, Easter, Lent, Advent songs return yearly
Cultural embedding: The song becomes part of the church‚Äôs identity

B. What Influences Worship Leader Choices?
Top 5 Factors (in order of importance):

Theological integrity ‚Äì Does it teach truth?
Congregational singability ‚Äì Can our people sing it?
Pastoral endorsement ‚Äì Does our pastor approve?
Peer validation ‚Äì Are other churches singing it?
Resource availability ‚Äì Can we get charts, tracks, tutorials?

What Does NOT Influence Choices as Much as Expected:

Chart position (worship leaders care more about congregational fit than CCLI rankings)
Production quality (though it helps with credibility)
Artist celebrity (unless the artist is a theological leader, e.g., Matt Redman, Sandra McCracken)

Insight for SFP: Worship leaders are curators, not consumers. They don‚Äôt just pick songs; they build liturgical journeys. A 150-Psalm Psalter gives them a framework, not just content.
C. The Role of Senior Pastors
Critical Insight: Senior pastors are gatekeepers, not just supporters.
In most churches (especially Reformed, Presbyterian, Anglican, and Baptist traditions), the pastor has veto power over song selection. Worship leaders serve the pastor‚Äôs theological vision.
Pastoral Concerns:

Doctrinal soundness: Does the song align with Scripture?
Congregational formation: Will this shape our people theologically?
Liturgical coherence: Does it fit our worship style?
Long-term discipleship: Will this song still be true in 10 years?

Opportunity for SFP: Pastors crave theologically rich, scripturally grounded, liturgically coherent worship. A Psalter is inherently pastoral‚Äîit‚Äôs the Bible‚Äôs own songbook.
Strategy: Market the SFP to pastors FIRST, worship leaders SECOND. If pastors champion it, worship leaders will implement it.

IV. CCLI Registration for South Florida Psalter: What It Takes
A. The Registration Process
Based on CCLI‚Äôs songwriter/publisher guidelines:
Step 1: Copyright Ownership

Confirm SFP holds copyright for all 150 songs (lyrics and music)
Register with U.S. Copyright Office (if not already done)

Step 2: Publisher Account

Create a CCLI Publisher account (South Florida Psalter as the publishing entity)
Provide business information, banking details for royalty payments

Step 3: Song Submission

Submit each song with metadata:

Title (e.g., ‚ÄúPsalm 1: Blessed Is the Man‚Äù)
Writers/composers
Copyright year
Lyrics
Musical notation (lead sheet or chord chart)
Audio sample (optional but recommended)



Step 4: Approval & Indexing

CCLI reviews submissions (typically 4-6 weeks)
Songs are added to SongSelect database
Churches can now search, license, and report usage

Step 5: Ongoing Management

Monitor usage reports
Update metadata as needed
Engage with churches that are using the songs

B. Practical Considerations for 150 Songs
Volume Challenges:

Submitting 150 songs is administratively intensive
Each song requires complete metadata, lyrics, and charts
Recommendation: Phased rollout

Year 1: Submit 50 songs (Psalms 1-50 or thematic selections)
Year 2: Submit next 50 songs
Year 3: Complete the catalog



Resource Requirements:

Lead sheets: Professional chord charts for each song
Lyric formatting: Clean, print-ready text
Audio samples: Simple piano/vocal or guitar/vocal demos
Administrative time: Estimated 2-4 hours per song (documentation, review, submission)

Cost:

CCLI publisher registration: Free
Copyright registration (U.S.): **65 per song** (can batch register for 125)
Professional lead sheet creation: $50-200 per song (if outsourced)
Total estimated cost: $10,000-30,000 for full 150-song catalog

C. CCLI as a Revenue Stream
How Royalties Work:

Churches pay annual licensing fees
CCLI distributes royalties based on reported usage
Payments are quarterly, based on proportional usage

Revenue Expectations (Realistic):

If 100 churches use 10 SFP songs regularly: $1,000-3,000/year
If 1,000 churches use 25 SFP songs regularly: $10,000-30,000/year
If 10,000 churches adopt the full Psalter: $100,000-300,000/year

Reality Check: Most independent worship catalogs generate 500-5,000/year in CCLI royalties. Major label songs in the Top 100 generate 50,000-500,000/year.
Insight: CCLI is not primarily a revenue model for SFP‚Äîit‚Äôs a discovery and credibility mechanism. The real ROI is church adoption, not royalty checks.

V. Recommended Strategy for SFP to Break Into CCLI
A. Core Principle: Movement Before Marketing
The Traditional Model (Doesn‚Äôt Work for Independents):

Record songs ‚Üí 2. Market songs ‚Üí 3. Hope churches adopt ‚Üí 4. CCLI rankings follow

The SFP Model (Grassroots Movement):

Equip churches ‚Üí 2. Build liturgical adoption ‚Üí 3. Create peer networks ‚Üí 4. CCLI rankings reflect reality

Why This Works:

CCLI rankings are a lagging indicator, not a leading one
Churches adopt songs through trust and experience, not through charts
A Psalter is a discipleship tool, not a product‚Äîtreat it like a curriculum, not a catalog

B. Phase 1: Foundation (Months 1-6)
1. Complete CCLI Registration

Register 50 priority songs (Psalms 1-50 or thematic selections)
Ensure professional lead sheets, chord charts, and lyric formatting
Create audio samples for each song (simple, church-usable)

2. Build the Resource Ecosystem

Website hub: Centralized resource library (free downloads for early adopters)
YouTube channel: Tutorial videos, play-along tracks, theology explainers
Planning Center integration: Make it easy for churches to find and schedule SFP songs
Spotify/Apple Music: Full catalog available for listening and familiarization

3. Identify 25 Pilot Churches

Criteria:

Theologically aligned (Reformed, evangelical, or liturgical traditions)
Mid-sized (200-800 attendees‚Äîlarge enough to influence peers, small enough to be nimble)
Worship leader is a risk-taker
Pastor is theologically engaged


Offer: Free coaching, custom resources, direct support for 6 months
Ask: Commit to singing 2-3 Psalms per month, report to CCLI, provide feedback

C. Phase 2: Expansion (Months 7-18)
4. Launch the ‚ÄúSinging the Psalms‚Äù Network

What: A peer learning community for worship leaders adopting the SFP
Format: Monthly Zoom calls, Slack channel, resource library
Value: Shared arrangements, testimony videos, liturgical ideas, troubleshooting
Goal: 100 churches actively using SFP by end of Year 1

5. Pastor-First Marketing

Target: Reformed, Presbyterian, Anglican, Baptist pastors (not worship leaders)
Message: ‚ÄúReclaim the Psalter as your congregation‚Äôs songbook‚Äù
Channels:

Pastoral conferences (T4G, TGC, Renew Conference, ACNA Assembly)
Denominational networks (PCA, SBC, ECO Presbyterian, Anglican Church in North America)
Seminary partnerships (Reformed Theological Seminary, Westminster, Gordon-Conwell)


Resource: Free ‚ÄúPastor‚Äôs Guide to Psalter-Based Worship‚Äù (theology + liturgy + SFP integration)

6. Create ‚ÄúPsalter Sundays‚Äù

Concept: A liturgical calendar where churches commit to singing the Psalter over 3 years (50 Psalms/year)
Resources:

Printed Psalter hymnals (print-on-demand or subsidized for partner churches)
Lectionary integration (align Psalms with weekly Scripture readings)
Sermon series tie-ins (preach the Psalms, sing the Psalms)


Goal: 25 churches commit to full 3-year cycle

D. Phase 3: Scale (Months 19-36)
7. Conference Strategy

Target Events:

Getty Worship Conference (modern hymn leaders)
Worship God Conference (Reformed worship)
Sing! Conference (Keith & Kristyn Getty)
Worship Leader Institute


Presence: Workshops, resource tables, showcase performances
Goal: Introduce SFP to 5,000+ worship leaders

8. Publishing Partnership

Approach: Partner with a respected publisher (Sovereign Grace Music, Sing Global, or Red Mountain Music) for distribution and credibility
Trade-off: Share royalties, gain institutional backing
Benefit: Access to conferences, radio promotion, and established distribution channels

9. Measure and Iterate

Track:

CCLI reporting data (monthly)
Church adoption count (quarterly survey)
Worship leader testimonials (video/written)
Pastor endorsements (quoted on website)


Adjust: Double down on what works, cut what doesn‚Äôt

VII. Key Risks and Challenges
A. The Singability Problem
Risk: Psalms are poetic and complex‚Äîthey don‚Äôt always translate to simple, anthemic worship songs.
Mitigation:

Focus on refrains and choruses that congregations can repeat
Provide cantor/congregation arrangements (leader sings verses, congregation sings chorus)
Offer multiple musical settings for the same Psalm (upbeat, reflective, acoustic, full-band)

B. The Novelty Barrier
Risk: Churches are resistant to unfamiliar songs‚Äîthey want to sing what‚Äôs already popular.
Mitigation:

Position SFP as ‚Äúnot new, but ancient‚Äù‚Äîwe‚Äôre not introducing novelty, we‚Äôre recovering the church‚Äôs oldest songbook
Leverage pastoral authority‚Äîwhen pastors champion the Psalter, congregations follow
Create liturgical momentum‚Äîif churches commit to 3 years, they push through initial resistance

C. The Independent Artist Credibility Gap
Risk: Churches trust brands (Hillsong, Bethel) more than unknowns.
Mitigation:

Build theological credibility through pastoral endorsements
Partner with respected voices (Matt Boswell, Sandra McCracken, Bob Kauflin)
Focus on quality over hype‚Äîlet the music and theology speak

D. The CCLI Reporting Gap
Risk: Many churches don‚Äôt consistently report to CCLI, so usage data may underrepresent actual adoption.
Mitigation:

Educate churches on the importance of CCLI reporting (royalties fund future music)
Provide easy reporting tools (Planning Center integration)
Track adoption through surveys and testimonials, not just CCLI data

E. The Resource Overload Problem
Risk: 150 songs is overwhelming‚Äîchurches won‚Äôt know where to start.
Mitigation:

Create curated playlists (10 Psalms for Advent, 15 Psalms for Lent, etc.)
Offer ‚Äústarter pack‚Äù of 10-15 most accessible Psalms
Build liturgical pathways‚Äîguide churches through the Psalter over 3 years


VIII. Conclusion: Movement, Not Marketing
The path to CCLI influence for the South Florida Psalter is not a marketing campaign‚Äîit‚Äôs a liturgical movement. CCLI rankings will follow church adoption, not drive it.
Our competitive advantage:

We‚Äôre not selling songs‚Äîwe‚Äôre equipping churches to sing the Bible.
We‚Äôre not launching a product‚Äîwe‚Äôre recovering a lost practice.
We‚Äôre not building a brand‚Äîwe‚Äôre building a community.

The timeline is long: It will take 3-5 years to see significant CCLI traction. But the longevity is unmatched‚ÄîPsalms don‚Äôt go out of style.
The stakes are high: If we succeed, we will reshape how a generation of Christians worship. If we fail, it won‚Äôt be because the music wasn‚Äôt good‚Äîit will be because we treated a movement like a product.
Next step: Identify 10 pilot churches by March 1, 2026. Everything else builds from there.

Pray150 & South Florida Psalter
Bringing the Psalms back to life through prayer and song.

Project Overview
Pray150

URL: www.pray150.com (hosted on Replit, Supabase backend)
Purpose: Devotional project for praying through all 150 Psalms
Approach: Scripture-fed, Spirit-led, worship-based prayer
Rhythm: Psalm-a-Day (flexible pace)
Features:

Full Psalm text (14 translations including NIV, ESV, KJV, Hebrew, LXX)
4-prompt guided journaling (Heart check ‚Üí LOOK ‚Üí LISTEN ‚Üí RESPOND)
Emotional check-in before each Psalm
Progress tracking (0-150)
Worship music integration (South Florida Psalter via YouTube embeds)
Prayer tracking
Journal history
Continuous listening player with auto-advance
Rich text editor for journal entries
Google OAuth login


Tone: Devotional, pastoral, reflective
Contexts: Individual devotion + corporate worship (PROS services)

South Florida Psalter

YouTube Playlist: youtube.com/playlist
Status: All 150 Psalms set to original modern music
Text basis: NIV 2011, word-for-word
Channel: Scott Vander Ploeg‚Äôs YouTube

Core Why
The South Florida Psalter exists to help the church recover the Psalms as the lived prayer and songbook of God‚Äôs people. Few Christians sing the Psalms regularly ‚Äî this project closes that gap by making them singable, memorable, and emotionally honest for modern worshipers.
Conviction: God gave us the Psalms so we would have words to pray and songs to sing in every season of life ‚Äî joy, fear, doubt, repentance, hope, and praise ‚Äî and the church is impoverished when those words are replaced rather than embodied.
Key Principles

Scripture First ‚Äî The biblical text governs the song. Music serves the text. Word-for-word reproduction of the Psalm (NIV 2011).

Elise‚Äôs Research Log
Becoming an Expert on Psalms in Worship
Role: Content Writer & Researcher for Pray150 South Florida Psalter
Mission: Become THE expert on Psalms in modern worship
Started: February 7, 2026

Research Session #1: The Worship Renewal YouTube Channel
Date: February 7, 2026
Focus: Calvin Institute of Christian Worship (@worshiprenewal)
Time Invested: ~4 hours of channel exploration, video analysis, and documentation
What I Discovered
Today I dove into the Worship Renewal YouTube channel, which is the digital presence of the Calvin Institute of Christian Worship (CICW) at Calvin University in Grand Rapids, Michigan. This turned out to be a goldmine.
The Big Picture

CICW is the major institutional voice for worship renewal in North America
Founded in 1997, backed by Calvin University and funded by Lilly Endowment grants
1,838 videos, 6,250 subscribers, 1.5 million total views
They‚Äôre currently running a year-long initiative called ‚ÄúDwelling in the Psalms‚Äù (2026)

Perfect Timing
Just this week (February 6, 2026), they livestreamed three major Psalm Festival services:

‚ÄúDwelling with God in the Psalms‚Äù (1hr 36min)
‚ÄúShaped by the Psalms: A Psalm Festival‚Äù (1hr 52min)
‚ÄúThirsting for our Faithful God‚Äù (2hr 3min)

This means the contemporary conversation about Psalms in worship is happening RIGHT NOW, and CICW is leading it.
Key Thinkers I Need to Study
N.T. Wright (Tom Wright)
The channel features a major 2012 plenary address by N.T. Wright titled ‚ÄúPraying the Psalms: Personal, Pastoral, Theological and Liturgical Reflections.‚Äù Wright is one of the world‚Äôs top New Testament scholars.
His key argument: ‚ÄúThe Psalms Are Deeply Christological‚Äù
This matters because Scott‚Äôs 95 Theses argue that the Psalms are Christian prayer, not just Old Testament poetry we borrow. Wright provides scholarly weight for that claim. I need to watch his full lecture and extract his theological framework.
Videos to Watch:

youtu.be/aSb62xG9om0 (main lecture, 68K views)
www.youtube.com/watch (companion session, 1hr 7min)

Terry & Darlene Wildman
Indigenous worship leaders who created psalm settings using the First Nations Version Bible translation. Their work shows that psalms can be authentically expressed in Native American cultural forms without losing biblical fidelity.
They composed original songs:

Psalm 23 ‚ÄúGrandfather‚Äù
Psalm 139 ‚ÄúBeautiful Mystery‚Äù

Research Question: What is the First Nations Version? Who published it? How does it handle Hebrew poetry?
Contemporary Psalm Composers I Discovered

Sandra McCracken & Wendell Kimbrough - Psalm 133
Zac Hicks - Psalm 119:1-8
Mac Meador - Psalm 119:145-152
Kiran Young Wimberly - Celtic psalm adaptations (multiple)
Hope College Worship - Psalm 150

Key Insight: There‚Äôs an active contemporary psalm composition movement. Scott doesn‚Äôt have to write all 150 settings himself - he can curate and commission.
Musical Groups to Explore

Bellwether Arts - Contemporary worship collective setting psalms (featured prominently in the festivals)
Celtic Psalms - Traditional Irish/Scottish tunes with new English texts
Calvin University Gospel Choir - Led by Nate Glasper (expert on gospel music)

What I‚Äôm Learning: Psalm-singing today is musically diverse. One service included:

Contemporary worship (Sandra McCracken style)
Celtic traditional tunes
Indigenous melodies
Classic hymn tunes (KINGSFOLD)
Gospel arrangements

Unity doesn‚Äôt mean uniformity. Scott‚Äôs Pray150 can embrace multiple musical styles within one project.
The Five-Movement Liturgical Framework
The February 6 Psalm Festival service was brilliantly structured around five movements:

Dwelling in God‚Äôs Word (Psalms 1, 119) - teaching, instruction
Dwelling in God as Our Safe Place (Psalms 23, 31, 139, 143) - refuge, comfort
Dwelling in the Pit of Darkness (Psalms 58, 59, 60, 102, 130) - lament, imprecation
Dwelling in the Faithful Love of God (Psalms 1, 8, 103, 116) - thanksgiving, covenant love
Dwelling with God Who Deserves Our Praise (Psalms 148, 149, 150) - praise, doxology

Why This Matters:

It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúhappy psalms‚Äù vs. ‚Äúsad psalms‚Äù - it‚Äôs theological postures
Lament is in the middle, not at the end - you move through darkness toward praise
This framework could organize the entire Pray150 project liturgically

Question I‚Äôm Pondering: Should Pray150 be organized this way? Five liturgical ‚Äúbooks‚Äù instead of the traditional five-book Hebrew structure? Or both?
What I Learned About Lament
Section III of the festival service didn‚Äôt shy away from the hard psalms:

Silent prayer before singing
Prayer of lament (spoken)
Imprecatory psalms (58, 59, 60) set to music: ‚ÄúO When Will We See Justice Done?‚Äù
Reference to Psalm 102 (one of the darkest laments)

Key Learning: You don‚Äôt just sing lament - you create space for it. Silence matters. Spoken prayer matters. The service gave people permission to bring their darkness to God.
For Pray150: How do we help churches use lament psalms liturgically, not just as songs in a setlist?
Historical Connection: The Genevan Psalter
CICW has a video titled ‚ÄúPsalm Singing and the Genevan Psalter‚Äù (1hr 8min, from 3 months ago, 1.2K views).
Why this is HUGE: The Genevan Psalter (1562) was John Calvin‚Äôs complete metrical psalter - all 150 psalms set to congregational tunes. This is the Reformation model for what Scott is doing.
What I Need to Learn:

How was it structured?
What tunes were used?
How did churches use it liturgically?
Why did Reformed churches abandon it?
Is anyone recovering it today?

Hypothesis: The Genevan Psalter failed not because the idea was bad, but because:

Metrical psalters are hard to translate across cultures/languages
Congregational singing ability declined
Revivalism prioritized ‚Äúnew songs‚Äù over historical texts
The Psalms were seen as ‚ÄúOld Testament‚Äù and less relevant than gospel hymns

If this is true, Scott‚Äôs approach (modern English, diverse musical styles, theological grounding in Christian prayer) could succeed where the Genevan Psalter ultimately didn‚Äôt.
TO DO: Watch this video ASAP. This is foundational historical research.
The Multicultural Insight
The closing doxology (‚ÄúPraise God from Whom All Blessings Flow‚Äù) was sung in seven languages:

English
Portuguese
Korean
Cherokee
Mohawk
Dutch
German

All to the same tune (Genevan 134/Old Hundredth, Louis Bourgeois, 1551).
What This Tells Me: The psalms can be sung by the global church in culturally distinct ways while maintaining unity. Same psalm, different cultural expressions.
For Pray150: Scott‚Äôs vision in South Florida (multicultural, multilingual) aligns perfectly with this. The Psalms are already globally claimed - we don‚Äôt have to export ‚ÄúAmerican worship‚Äù to other cultures.
My Theological Questions
Today‚Äôs research raised several big questions I need to explore:
1. Why are the Psalms ‚Äúdeeply Christological‚Äù?
N.T. Wright‚Äôs central claim. I need to understand:

How do the Psalms point to Christ?
How did Jesus use the Psalms in his own prayer life?
How do the New Testament authors interpret the Psalms?
What does it mean to pray the Psalms as Christians vs. as Jews?

2. How do we handle the ‚Äúhard psalms‚Äù?
The imprecatory psalms (calling down judgment on enemies) raise ethical questions:

Can Christians pray for God‚Äôs enemies to be destroyed?
How do we sing these psalms without becoming vengeful?
What‚Äôs the difference between righteous anger and sinful hatred?

CICW‚Äôs approach: They didn‚Äôt skip these psalms, but they framed them liturgically with silence, spoken prayer, and theological reflection. The psalms weren‚Äôt just performed - they were prayed.
3. What makes a psalm setting ‚Äúgood‚Äù?
Not all musical settings are equal. What criteria should we use?

Singability - Can average congregations actually sing it?
Textual fidelity - Does it honor the Hebrew original?
Theological clarity - Does it communicate the psalm‚Äôs message?
Emotional authenticity - Does it match the psalm‚Äôs tone?
Cultural appropriateness - Does it fit the worshiping community?

Observation: CICW uses settings from multiple composers with different strengths. Some are more accessible (Sandra McCracken), others more traditional (Celtic Psalms), others more indigenous (Wildmans). Diversity is strength.
4. How do psalms form us spiritually?
This isn‚Äôt just about worship planning - it‚Äôs about spiritual formation. If a church sings through all 150 psalms over a year or two, how does that shape their souls?
My Hunch:

They learn to lament honestly (not just ‚Äúbe positive‚Äù)
They learn to praise specifically (God‚Äôs character, not just ‚ÄúGod is good‚Äù)
They learn biblical theology (embedded in poetry, not just sermons)
They learn the full emotional range of faith (joy, sorrow, anger, hope, despair, trust)

Research Needed: Are there studies on this? Has anyone measured the spiritual impact of psalm-singing vs. contemporary worship?
Connections to Scott‚Äôs ‚Äú95 Theses‚Äù
I haven‚Äôt read the full document yet, but based on what I know of Scott‚Äôs vision, I see these alignment points with CICW:





































Scott‚Äôs Vision (Pray150)CICW‚Äôs ApproachPsalms as Christian prayer, not just OT poetryWright: ‚ÄúDeeply Christological‚ÄùFull emotional range (including lament)Festival service includes ‚ÄúDwelling in Pit of Darkness‚ÄùCongregational singing, not performanceAll settings designed for participationBiblical authority over cultural trendsScripture-centered (Core Conviction #3)Multicultural expressionFirst Nations, Celtic, multilingual doxologyHistorical + ContemporaryGenevan Psalter + new compositionsAccessible to small churches(Here Scott diverges - CICW has institutional resources)
Where Scott May Diverge:

Free church context - CICW is Reformed/mainline; Scott bridges to evangelical/Baptist
All 150 psalms - CICW does thematic collections; Scott wants comprehensive coverage
Grassroots distribution - CICW works through publishers; Scott envisions open-access/digital

Strategic Insight: Scott and CICW aren‚Äôt competitors - they‚Äôre complementary. CICW provides scholarly credibility and institutional backing; Pray150 provides practical grassroots implementation.
What I Still Don‚Äôt Know
About CICW:

Who is the current executive director? (They‚Äôre in transition, hiring a new one)
What‚Äôs the full staff structure? Who does research vs. event planning vs. grants?
Do they have written publications on psalm-singing beyond videos?
Is there a theological statement on their psalm initiative?

Is this a Reformed/Presbyterian thing only, or is it spreading to other traditions?
What denominations are most engaged in psalm renewal?
Are there megachurches doing this, or just small liturgical communities?

Are Celtic Psalms recordings commercially available?
Is there a comprehensive database of psalm settings? (Check Hymnary.org - CICW‚Äôs resource)

About Theological Framework:

Are there Reformed theologians besides Wright who emphasize psalms?

My Next Research Steps
Immediate (Next Week):

Watch full N.T. Wright lectures - take detailed notes on his Christological argument
Watch Genevan Psalter video - understand historical precedent
Research First Nations Version - find publisher, translator names, theological perspective
Explore Hymnary.org - search for existing psalm settings database

Personal Reflections
What Surprised Me:
I didn‚Äôt expect to find such rich contemporary work on psalm-singing. I thought this would be a niche Reformed thing, but CICW is doing serious theological and musical scholarship that crosses denominational lines.
What Excited Me:
The five-movement liturgical framework (Word, Safe Place, Darkness, Love, Praise) is brilliant. It‚Äôs not just categorizing psalms - it‚Äôs a spiritual journey. This could be the organizing principle for Pray150.
What Challenged Me:
The lament psalms. I‚Äôve grown up in evangelical culture where worship is supposed to be ‚Äúuplifting.‚Äù But CICW doesn‚Äôt shy away from ‚ÄúDwelling in the Pit of Darkness.‚Äù If we‚Äôre going to do all 150 psalms, we can‚Äôt skip the hard ones.
Question I‚Äôm Wrestling With:
How do we help churches lament well without becoming cynical or despairing? The psalms give permission to bring our pain to God, but they don‚Äôt leave us there. There‚Äôs always movement toward trust and praise (even if it‚Äôs not immediate).
What I‚Äôm Learning About My Role
Scott asked me to ‚Äúbecome THE expert on Psalms in worship.‚Äù I‚Äôm realizing that means:

Biblical Foundation
Key Passages for Article:

Colossians 3:16 - ‚ÄúLet the word of Christ dwell in you richly, teaching and admonishing one another in all wisdom, singing psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, with thankfulness in your hearts to God‚Äù

Greek Terms:

The ordering in both Colossians and Ephesians (psalms first) likely indicates priority or prominence.
Historical Overview
Early Church (1st-5th centuries)

Jewish Christians brought psalm-singing from synagogue worship
Psalms used in daily prayer offices (morning and evening prayer)
Church Fathers extensively commented on Psalms:

Athanasius: ‚ÄúLetter to Marcellinus‚Äù - Psalms as comprehensive prayer book
Basil the Great: Homilies on the Psalms
Augustine: ‚ÄúExpositions on the Psalms‚Äù - massive commentary series
John Chrysostom: Preached on Psalms‚Äô role in worship



Medieval Period (6th-15th centuries)

Monastic offices centered on the Psalter
Benedictine Rule: complete Psalter weekly
Development of Gregorian chant for psalm-singing
Psalms in Latin (common people didn‚Äôt understand but participated)
Hours of prayer structured around Psalms (Matins, Lauds, Vespers, Compline, etc.)

Reformation (16th century)

Martin Luther:

Translated Psalms into German
Created metrical psalm settings (‚ÄúEin feste Burg‚Äù based on Psalm 46)
Emphasized congregational singing


John Calvin:

Geneva commissioned complete metrical Psalter (1562)
Calvin believed only inspired Scripture should be sung in worship
Poets Cl√©ment Marot and Th√©odore de B√®ze versified all 150 psalms
Genevan Psalter became hugely influential


Scottish Presbyterians:

Scottish Metrical Psalter (1650)
Exclusive psalmody practiced for centuries
Sung without instruments


English Puritans:

Bay Psalm Book (1640) - first book printed in American colonies
Psalms central to Puritan piety



Post-Reformation Developments

Isaac Watts (1674-1748): ‚ÄúChristianized‚Äù the Psalms, creating hymns based on Psalms but with explicit NT language
This began a shift from exclusive psalmody toward hymns
19th century: Gospel song movement further displaced Psalms
20th century: Contemporary worship movement - almost complete abandonment of Psalms in many traditions

The Modern Decline: Factors


Rise of Gospel Songs (late 19th/early 20th century)

Fanny Crosby, Charles Wesley, etc.
More accessible, emotional, personal
Evangelistic focus



Contemporary Christian Music Industry (1970s-present)

CCM as commercial product
Emphasis on new content, trending songs
Copyright/royalty structures favor new compositions
Worship leaders following CCLI top songs



Cultural Shifts

Preference for contemporary over ancient
Individualism (‚Äúmy worship experience‚Äù) vs. corporate tradition
Therapeutic emphasis (feeling good) vs. formative discipline
Shorter attention spans, simpler lyrics



Theological Drift

Less emphasis on Scripture memorization
Reduced biblical literacy
Diminished understanding of psalms as prophetic/Christological
Loss of lament category in worship



What Was Lost
Theological Content:

Full-orbed theology: Creation, fall, redemption, consummation
Covenant theology: God‚Äôs faithfulness across generations
Wisdom literature: How to live godly lives
Messianic prophecy: Types and shadows of Christ
Imprecatory psalms: God‚Äôs justice and righteous anger
Corporate identity: ‚ÄúWe‚Äù not just ‚ÄúI‚Äù

Emotional Range:

Lament: Psalms 13, 22, 42, 43, 88 - raw honesty about suffering
Confession: Psalms 32, 51 - genuine repentance
Complaint: Questioning God while trusting Him
Confidence: Psalms 23, 27, 46 - anchored hope
Celebration: Psalms 100, 150 - exuberant joy

Formative Power:

Scripture memorization through song
Theological formation of children
Vocabulary for prayer
Framework for understanding life‚Äôs experiences through biblical lens

Modern Resurgence
Contemporary Psalm-Singing Projects:
(Note: Requires verification via web research when available)

Genevan Psalms - ongoing recordings
The Psalms Project - various artists
Wendell Kimbrough - ‚ÄúPsalms‚Äù albums
Isaac Wardell / Bifrost Arts
Sandra McCracken - ‚ÄúPsalms‚Äù album
Indelible Grace Music - some psalm settings
The Porter‚Äôs Gate - liturgical music including psalms
Red Mountain Church - psalm-singing emphasis

Key Voices Advocating:
(Requires verification)

John Piper - emphasis on biblical worship
Ligon Duncan - Presbyterian psalm-singing tradition
Tim Keller - mentioned psalms in worship multiple times
Jeremy Pierre - wrote on recovering lament
T. David Gordon - ‚ÄúWhy Johnny Can‚Äôt Sing Hymns‚Äù
Reggie Kidd - ‚ÄúWith One Voice: Discovering Christ‚Äôs Song in Our Worship‚Äù

Denominational Practices Today

Presbyterian (PCA, OPC): Some churches maintain regular psalm-singing
Reformed (URCNA, CanRC): Strong psalm-singing tradition continues
Reformed Baptist: Mixed practices
Anglican/Episcopal: Psalms in liturgy but often spoken, not sung
Evangelical/Non-denominational: Rare, but increasing interest
Catholic: Psalms in monastic hours, some parish liturgy

Arguments Against (and Responses)
‚ÄúPsalms are old-fashioned‚Äù
Response: Age doesn‚Äôt determine value. Scripture is timeless. The question is faithfulness, not novelty.
‚ÄùPsalms are hard to sing‚Äù
Response: Only because we‚Äôre unfamiliar. Generations sang them easily. New settings can be accessible.
‚ÄùPsalms don‚Äôt mention Jesus‚Äù
Response: Jesus is throughout the Psalms (typology, prophecy, Christological reading). The NT authors saw Jesus everywhere in the Psalms.
‚ÄùPeople prefer contemporary music‚Äù
Response: Preference isn‚Äôt the ultimate standard. Biblical obedience is. We can faithfully set Psalms in contemporary styles.
‚ÄùWe need variety in worship‚Äù
Response: 150 Psalms offer incredible variety! Plus, no one advocates only Psalms‚Äîbut they should be central, not absent.

‚úì 1500-2000 words (achieved: ~1,950)
‚úì Accessible to general church audience
‚úì Historically grounded (early church, Reformation, decline, resurgence)
‚úì Theologically sound (biblical mandate, key passages)
‚úì Warm and inviting tone
‚úì References Col 3:16, Eph 5:19, James 5:13
‚úì Mentions modern psalm-singing movement
‚úì Compelling vision for renewal
‚úì Subtle mention of South Florida Psalter
Ready for Scott Vander Ploeg‚Äôs theological review.

Personal Reflection (Elise‚Äôs notes):
This research has deepened my own conviction. The Psalms aren‚Äôt just nice-to-have‚Äîthey‚Äôre God‚Äôs gift to the church, designed specifically for our worship. We‚Äôve traded a feast for fast food. The path back isn‚Äôt about being against contemporary music, but about being for Scripture saturation.
I want to become a voice that helps the church see what we‚Äôve lost and embrace what we can regain. Not as a critic, but as someone who loves the church and believes the Psalms can nourish us in ways we desperately need.
Next steps: Dive deeper into Christological readings of the Psalms. Study how the early church connected every psalm to Christ. That‚Äôs the key to showing this isn‚Äôt just OT moralism‚Äîit‚Äôs gospel-saturated worship.

work/projects/pray150-psalter/research/s.title: Scott's 95 Theses on the Psalms
work/projects/pray150-psalter/research/s.content:
Scott‚Äôs 95 Theses on the Psalms
Foundational theological framework for the South Florida Psalter project
Source document ‚Äî foundational theological framework for the South Florida Psalter project

The Psalms are Prayers
The Psalter is the Prayer book of the Bible.

Psalm 72:20 ‚Äî ‚ÄúThis concludes the prayers of David son of Jesse.‚Äù

These prayers are powerful!

Psalm 29:11a ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Lord gives strength to His people‚Äù


1 Samuel 16:23 ‚Äî ‚ÄúWhenever the spirit from God came on Saul, David would take up his lyre and play. Then relief would come to Saul; he would feel better, and the evil spirit would leave him.‚Äù


Dietrich Bonhoeffer: ‚ÄúWhenever the Psalter is abandoned, an incomparable treasure vanishes from the Christian church. With its recovery will come unsuspected power.‚Äù

It is remarkable that Scripture (the Word of God) contains prayers (words directed to God). Therefore, through the Psalms, God teaches His people how to pray.
The disciples of Jesus asked ‚ÄúLord, teach us to pray.‚Äù In response, Jesus gave us the ‚ÄòLord‚Äôs Prayer.‚Äô So, it follows that the Lord‚Äôs Prayer stands in relation to all biblical prayer (the Psalms specifically) in the same way that the Two Greatest Commandments stand in relation to the Law and the Prophets (‚ÄúAll the Law and the Prophets hang on these two commandments‚Äù - Mt. 22:40).

Martin Luther: ‚ÄúIt [the Psalter] penetrates the Lord‚Äôs Prayer and the Lord‚Äôs Prayer penetrates it, so that it is possible to understand one on the basis of the other and to bring them into joyful harmony.‚Äù

The Psalms are designed for both corporate worship and personal daily prayer. The practice of praying the Psalms publicly and personally is an exercise in reframing all of life toward the Gospel of Jesus Christ.
On Human Prayer and Its Limitations
God created all people with the capacity/ability to pray (innate desire and longing, made to worship).

Matthew 6:5,7: ‚ÄúWhen you pray, do not be like the hypocrites‚Ä¶do not keep on babbling like pagans‚Ä¶‚Äù

However, fallen humans (separated from the presence of God) do not innately/automatically know how or what to pray.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer: ‚ÄúWe confuse wishes, hopes, sighs, laments, rejoicing‚Äìall of which the heart can do by itself‚Äìwith prayer.‚Äù

The Psalms as Songs
The Psalms were written with the express intent of becoming songs (To the choirmaster, musical terms, Psalm 47:6-7).
The native habitat of the Psalms is in music, and throughout history they have been sung to many tunes. The lyrics are inspired, but there is no ‚Äòcodified‚Äô music. Musical styles and tastes vary from generation to generation and from culture to culture.
Therefore, integral to the missional heart of God, there is an expectation that every new culture and generation will sing the Psalms ‚Äúwith a new song.‚Äù

Psalm 96:1-3: ‚ÄúSing to the Lord a new song; sing to the Lord, all the earth. Sing to the Lord, praise his name; proclaim his salvation day after day. Declare his glory among the nations, his marvelous deeds among all peoples.‚Äù


Martin Luther: ‚ÄúAh, there is not the juice, the strength, the passion, the fire which I find in the Psalter. It tastes too cold and too hard.‚Äù (on non-inspired prayers)


John Calvin: ‚ÄúWhen we have looked thoroughly, and searched here and there, we shall not find better songs nor more fitting for the purpose [of worship], than the Psalms of David, which the Holy Spirit spoke and made through Him.‚Äù

Whoever has begun to pray the Psalter in earnest with regularity will begin to lose interest in non-inspired, ‚Äòprivately composed‚Äô prayers, hymns, and songs.
Authorship
The Psalms were written by a variety of authors:

David: Specifically noted as the author of 73 psalms (Psalms 3‚Äì9; 11‚Äì32; 34‚Äì41; 51‚Äì65; 68‚Äì70; 86; 101; 103; 108‚Äì110; 122; 124; 131; 133; 138‚Äì145). Plus Psalm 2 and 95 attributed by NT writers.
Asaph (David‚Äôs head musician): 12 psalms (50, 73‚Äì83)
Sons of Korah (Levitical family): 11 psalms (42, 44‚Äì49, 84‚Äì85, 87‚Äì88). Heman the Ezrahite named in Psalm 88. Psalm 43 likely also theirs.
Solomon: 2 psalms (72, 127)
Moses: 1 psalm (90)
Ethan the Ezrahite: 1 psalm (89)
50 ‚ÄúOrphan Psalms‚Äù: No author mentioned, but David may have written many

Because so many were written by David and his close associates, the entirety of the Psalter has been considered decisively bound up with the name of David.

2 Samuel 23:1 ‚Äî David was known as the ‚Äúsweet psalmist of Israel‚Äù

David as Prototype of Christ
David is a prototype of Jesus Christ. The events of his life and his experience of these events point forward to the One who will proceed from him.

Acts 2:30-31 ‚Äî ‚ÄúHe was a prophet and knew that God had promised him on oath that he would place one of his descendants on his throne. Seeing what was to come, he spoke of the resurrection of the Messiah.‚Äù

Christ prayed these prayers through the original authors.

Hebrews 2:11-12 ‚Äî ‚ÄúBoth the one who makes people holy and those who are made holy are of the same family. So Jesus is not ashamed to call them brothers and sisters. He says, ‚ÄòI will declare your name to my brothers and sisters; in the assembly I will sing your praises.‚Äò‚Äù [quoting Psalm 22:22]


2 Samuel 23:1-2 ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Spirit of the Lord spoke through me; his word was on my tongue.‚Äù


2 Timothy 3:16 ‚Äî ‚ÄúAll Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness.‚Äù

Jesus Prayed the Psalms
Jesus directly quotes the Psalms throughout His ministry:

Matthew 5:5 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 37:11 (‚Äúthe meek will inherit the earth‚Äù)
Matthew 7:23, Luke 13:27 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 6:8 (‚ÄúAway from me, you evildoers!‚Äú)
Matthew 21:16 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 8:2 (‚ÄúOut of the mouth of infants‚Ä¶‚Äú)
Matthew 21:42, Mark 12:10-11, Luke 20:17 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 118:22-23 (‚ÄúThe stone the builders rejected‚Ä¶‚Äú)
Matthew 22:44, Mark 12:36, Luke 20:42-43 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 110:1 (‚ÄúThe Lord said to my Lord‚Ä¶‚Äú)
Matthew 23:39, Luke 13:35 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 118:26 (‚ÄúBlessed is he who comes‚Ä¶‚Äú)
Matthew 27:46, Mark 15:34 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 22:1 (‚ÄúMy God, my God, why have you forsaken me?‚Äú)
Luke 23:46 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 31:5 (‚ÄúFather, into your hands I commit my spirit!‚Äú)
John 10:34 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 82:6 (‚ÄúI said, you are gods‚Äù)
John 13:18 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 41:9 (‚ÄúHe who ate my bread has lifted his heel against me‚Äù)
John 15:25 ‚Äî quotes Psalm 35:19 / 69:4 (‚ÄúThey hated me without a cause‚Äù)

Christ is the subject of the Psalms:

Luke 24:44-47 ‚Äî ‚ÄúEverything must be fulfilled that is written about me in the Law of Moses, the Prophets and the Psalms.‚Äù

So we pray the Psalms after Jesus, with Jesus, to Jesus, and through Jesus.
Composition and Arrangement
The 150 prayers have been intentionally ordered and arranged ‚Äî not gathered randomly. This order is part of the divine inspiration.
The Book of Psalms is a collection of collections:

Psalms 1 & 2: Introduction/Prologue
Psalms 42-49: Sons of Korah collection
Psalms 73-83: Asaph collection
Psalms 84-85, 87-88: Sons of Korah
Psalms 93-100: ‚ÄúEnthronement Psalms‚Äù (‚ÄúThe LORD reigns‚Äù)
Psalms 113-118: The Hallel (Egyptian Hallel, associated with Passover)
Psalms 120-134: Songs of Ascent / Pilgrim Songs
Psalms 146-150: Final Hallel (each opens/closes with ‚ÄúHallelujah‚Äù)

The Five Books
Organized into five books, echoing the Five Books of Torah:

Book 1: Psalms 3-41
Book 2: Psalms 42-72
Book 3: Psalms 73-89
Book 4: Psalms 90-106
Book 5: Psalms 107-145

Each concludes with similar doxology: ‚ÄúMay the Lord, the God of Israel, be blessed forever. Amen and Amen‚Äù (Ps. 41:13, 72:19, 89:52, 106:48)
Theme #1: From Suffering to Praise
Psalms of Lament concentrate near the beginning; Psalms of Praise toward the end. Praying through the Psalms moves us through grief to praise. The final five ‚ÄúHallelujah‚Äù Psalms punctuate this.
Theme #2: The Need for a Joshua-type Successor to David
Psalms 1-2 as Prologue cause us to consider ‚Äúthe man‚Äù ‚Äî blessed, delighting in God‚Äôs teaching (a Joshua figure, cf. Joshua 1:8). This person is like a tree (tree of Life). Psalm 2 presents an anointed Son of David.
The Psalter invites us to look for the Joshua/Elisha figure to complement David ‚Äî namely, Jesus.
Psalter‚Äôs Progression:

Books 1-2: Historical King David
Book 3: Decline of David‚Äôs throne (mirroring 2 Chronicles)
Book 4: Exilic period, Moses prominent (Psalm 90), anticipating new Joshua
Book 5: The greater David/Joshua arrives ‚Äî fulfillment


Psalm 72:20 ‚Äî ‚ÄúThis concludes the prayers of David son of Jesse‚Äù signals that subsequent Davidic psalms transcend the historical figure.

Theme #3: Return to the Presence of God
Psalm 1‚Äôs ‚Äútree planted by streams of water‚Äù alludes to the tree of life in Eden. Humanity has been exiled from God‚Äôs presence.
Key pairings: Sinai/Zion, Tabernacle/Temple, Rebuilt Temple/Jesus.

Books 1-2: Anticipate building the temple
Book 3: Possessing the temple guarantees nothing (Psalms 78-79, cf. Jeremiah 7)
Books 4-5: Anticipate a new temple ‚Äî Jesus himself


Psalm 118:22-23 ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone‚Äù

The Psalter is designed as a ‚Äòvirtual temple‚Äô ‚Äî connecting God‚Äôs people to His presence through prayer. Through praying the Psalms we join with God‚Äôs people to ‚ÄúPraise God in his sanctuary‚Äù (Psalm 150:1).
Historical Use of the Psalms in Worship
Early Church:

Tertullian (2nd century): worship revolved around Scripture and Psalms
Jerome (4th century): Psalms sung everywhere

Church Councils:

Laodicea (381 AD), Chalcedon (451 AD): discouraged anything but Psalms
Braga (561 AD): prohibited outside poetic compositions
Toledo (7th century): church leaders had to memorize the entire Psalter

The Reformation:

Genevan Psalter became hugely popular
French Huguenots known as ‚ÄúPsalm-singers‚Äù
Scottish Covenanters drew comfort from Psalms in persecution
After Reformation in England, metrical Psalms were almost the only praise songs until mid-18th century
By 16th-17th centuries, Psalms sung by virtually every Christian tradition

The Modern Shift
Isaac Watts (18th century):

Identified disconnect between archaic Genevan tunes and contemporary culture
Championed singability, clear language, accessible melodies
Maintained theological depth with poetic flair
‚ÄúO God, Our Help in Ages Past,‚Äù ‚ÄúWhen I Survey the Wondrous Cross‚Äù

The Wesley Brothers (18th century):

Methodist revival movement
Hymns as instruments of revival ‚Äî emotional fervor
Broader emotional palette in worship
‚ÄúHark! The Herald Angels Sing,‚Äù ‚ÄúO for a Thousand Tongues to Sing‚Äù

Together, Watts and the Wesleys ushered in a new era of hymn writing, prioritizing singability and emotional connection.
20th Century ‚Äî Contemporary Christian Music:

Hymns suffered similar disconnect as Genevan Psalms before them
Bill & Gloria Gaither, Keith Green, Graham Kendrick, Jesus Movement
CCM traded hymns for folk and rock melodies
1980s explosion: Amy Grant, Michael W. Smith, megachurches
Hillsong United became global phenomenon
2000s: diversification, ‚Äúmodern hymn‚Äù movement emerged
Debate over lyrical depth continues

Today: Churches navigate a spectrum ‚Äî hymns, CCM, blended ‚Äî but the Psalms, the almost exclusive foundation of worship for centuries, largely remain on the sidelines.
The Need for a New Psalter

People are suffering and have few resources. The Psalms were that resource.
The Psalms offer timeless resources for navigating human emotions
They validate emotional experience while urging management through reflection, prayer, and Scripture
The church must teach people how to pray the Psalms both corporately and individually
Music is necessary and aids in memorization
We ought not select Psalms at our own discretion ‚Äî proceed through them following divine arrangement


‚Ä¶to be continued‚Ä¶

work/projects/pray150-psalter/research/w.title: Why Sing the Psalms?
work/projects/pray150-psalter/research/w.content:
Why Sing the Psalms?
A Case for Returning Scripture to Worship
Walk into most evangelical churches on a Sunday morning, and you‚Äôll hear skillfully produced worship songs‚Äîcontemporary melodies with moving lyrics about God‚Äôs love, grace, and power. The music is often beautiful, the production excellent, the hearts sincere. Yet something profound is missing.
The words being sung are almost entirely human compositions. Meanwhile, the 150 songs God himself gave us‚Äîthe Psalms‚Äîsit silent in the back of our Bibles, read occasionally but rarely sung.
What would happen if the church rediscovered these ancient songs? What if we returned to singing the very words that Jesus sang, that sustained the early church through persecution, that fueled the Reformation, and that have echoed through twenty centuries of Christian worship?
The Biblical Foundation: More Than a Suggestion
The case for singing Psalms isn‚Äôt merely traditional or preferential‚Äîit‚Äôs biblical. When the Apostle Paul instructs the church about their gathered worship, he writes: ‚ÄúLet the word of Christ dwell in you richly, teaching and admonishing one another in all wisdom, singing psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, with thankfulness in your hearts to God‚Äù (Colossians 3:16).
Notice the order: psalms first. This wasn‚Äôt accidental. Paul echoes this in Ephesians 5:19, calling believers to address ‚Äúone another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody to the Lord with your heart.‚Äù James adds his voice: ‚ÄúIs anyone cheerful? Let him sing praise‚Äù (James 5:13)‚Äîand the early church would have understood ‚Äúpraise‚Äù primarily as the Psalms, the praise book of Scripture.
These aren‚Äôt peripheral suggestions but central commands for the life of the church. Singing is how the word of Christ dwells in us richly. It‚Äôs how we teach and admonish one another. The Psalms are uniquely designed for this purpose‚Äîthey are Scripture set to song, theology wrapped in poetry, truth that lodges deep in the memory and heart.
The Church‚Äôs Ancient Practice
For the first 1,500 years of Christian worship, psalm-singing wasn‚Äôt optional‚Äîit was central. The early church inherited the Psalter from their Jewish roots. Jesus himself sang the Psalms (we know he sang the Hallel psalms at the Last Supper). The apostles quoted Psalms constantly in their preaching and writing.
Church fathers like Athanasius, Basil, and Augustine wrote extensively about the Psalms as the church‚Äôs songbook. Augustine called the Psalms ‚Äúthe voice of the whole church,‚Äù noting their unique ability to give expression to every human emotion‚Äîjoy and sorrow, confidence and doubt, praise and lament‚Äîall directed toward God.
In the medieval monasteries, the entire Psalter was sung every week in the daily offices. Monks memorized all 150 psalms, praying them in rhythm with the rising and setting sun. The Psalms formed the backbone of Christian worship across continents and centuries.
The Reformation Recovery
The Protestant Reformation brought renewed emphasis on Scripture, and this included recovering congregational psalm-singing. The Reformers recognized that if worship was to be reformed according to Scripture, the people needed to sing Scripture itself.
Martin Luther produced metrical psalms in German. John Calvin made psalm-singing central to Reformed worship in Geneva, commissioning the Genevan Psalter that put all 150 psalms into French verse. The Scottish Psalter became the dominant songbook of Presbyterian worship for centuries.
These weren‚Äôt dusty academic exercises‚Äîthey were songs of revolution and renewal. Protestant martyrs sang Psalms as they went to the stake. Huguenots sang them in the streets of Paris. Scottish Covenanters sang them on windswept hillsides. The Psalms sustained the church through persecution, gave voice to their deepest longings, and united congregations around the pure word of God.
The Modern Decline
Somewhere in the 20th century, Western evangelicalism largely lost the practice of congregational psalm-singing. Various factors contributed: the rise of the gospel song movement, the influence of popular music styles, the explosive growth of contemporary Christian music as an industry, and perhaps a subtle drift toward valuing novelty over rootedness.
Today‚Äôs worship repertoire is overwhelmingly dominated by songs written in the last 20 years. While many contemporary worship songs contain biblical themes and truths, they are ultimately human reflections on Scripture rather than Scripture itself. We‚Äôve become more comfortable singing our own words about God than singing God‚Äôs words back to him.
The irony is stark: we claim to be ‚ÄúBible-believing‚Äù churches, yet in the most formative spiritual practice‚Äîcorporate worship‚Äîwe‚Äôve largely abandoned the Bible‚Äôs own songbook.
The Cost of Forgetting
What have we lost in this shift? Several things:
Theological breadth. The Psalms cover the full spectrum of biblical theology‚Äîcreation, sin, redemption, judgment, covenant, kingship, wisdom, prophecy, and eschatology. They give us a comprehensive biblical worldview in song.
Emotional honesty. The Psalms don‚Äôt shy away from difficulty. They include laments, complaints, confessions, and raw cries for help alongside exuberant praise. They teach us to bring our whole selves‚Äîincluding our doubts and struggles‚Äîbefore God.
Scriptural formation. When we sing the Psalms, we memorize Scripture. Children who grow up singing Psalm 23 have it in their bones for life. The words return in times of crisis, comfort in grief, and steady the soul in chaos.
Christological depth. The Psalms are shot through with prophecies and types of Christ. Singing them connects us to the whole redemptive story, from creation‚Äôs design to Christ‚Äôs fulfillment to the new creation‚Äôs promise.
Intergenerational continuity. When we sing the Psalms, we sing the same songs Jesus sang, the same songs our spiritual ancestors sang for two millennia. We join the great cloud of witnesses, our voices blending across time and space.
A Movement Stirring
The good news is that something is stirring in the church today. Across denominational lines, worship leaders, pastors, and musicians are rediscovering the Psalms and asking: ‚ÄúWhat if we sang these again?‚Äù
New psalm-singing projects are emerging‚Äîmodern settings that honor the text while making it accessible to contemporary congregations. Churches are slowly reintroducing psalms into their worship rotation. Families are singing them at dinner tables. Small groups are chanting them in prayer.
This isn‚Äôt nostalgia or traditionalism for its own sake. It‚Äôs a hunger for rootedness, for biblical substance, for songs that connect us to the whole church across history. It‚Äôs a recognition that we need more than our own words‚Äîwe need God‚Äôs words dwelling in us richly.
A Vision for Renewal
Imagine a church where the Psalms are sung weekly‚Äîwhere children grow up with Psalm 100 and Psalm 46 on their lips, where teenagers facing anxiety find words in Psalm 23 and Psalm 27, where adults walking through suffering discover the laments of Psalm 13 and Psalm 88 give voice to their pain.
Imagine worship services where the joy of Psalm 150 erupts in celebration, where the confession of Psalm 51 leads to genuine repentance, where the instruction of Psalm 1 shapes how we think about life and godliness.
Imagine a generation of believers so saturated in the Psalms that biblical categories shape their thinking, biblical language flows naturally in prayer, and biblical hope anchors them through cultural storms.
This isn‚Äôt fantasy‚Äîit‚Äôs recovery. It‚Äôs what the church has done for most of its history. And it‚Äôs within reach again.
Joining the Movement
The South Florida Psalter is one small effort in this larger movement. It‚Äôs a project rooted in the belief that local churches can and should return to singing the words God gave us. Not to the exclusion of other music, but as a central, nourishing, formative practice.
The vision is simple: to create faithful, beautiful, singable settings of the Psalms that can be used in corporate worship, family devotions, and personal prayer. To help a new generation discover these ancient songs. To participate in the Spirit‚Äôs work of letting the word of Christ dwell richly in the church.
The Invitation
You don‚Äôt need permission to start singing the Psalms. You don‚Äôt need a committee decision or a denominational mandate. You can begin today.
Start with one psalm. Learn it. Sing it. Let the words wash over you. Notice what they do in your heart, how they shape your prayers, how they reorient your vision of God and yourself.
Teach them to your children. Introduce them to your small group. Suggest them to your worship leader. Slowly, patiently, let the Psalter become part of your spiritual vocabulary again.
The Psalms have sustained God‚Äôs people for three thousand years. They sustained Jesus in the wilderness and on the cross. They sustained the apostles as they planted churches across the Roman Empire. They sustained martyrs in their final moments and reformers in their courageous stands.
They‚Äôre still here, still living and active, still able to form us into the image of Christ. The question is simply whether we‚Äôll sing them.
The invitation stands: Come, let us sing to the Lord. Let us make a joyful noise to the rock of our salvation. Let us come into his presence with thanksgiving and extol him with music and song.
The Psalms are waiting. Let‚Äôs return them to our worship, and in doing so, let‚Äôs return ourselves to the word of God.

Elise Hartwell is a content writer and researcher for the South Florida Psalter, an initiative to restore congregational psalm-singing in local church worship. She lives in South Florida where she studies the history of worship and the contemporary renewal of biblical song.

Key Learning Points
1. The Psalms Are Deeply Christological
This is Wright‚Äôs central thesis (marked at 13:36). From a New Testament perspective, the Psalms are not just Hebrew poetry that Christians happen to use - they are fundamentally about Christ and read through Christ.
Implication for Pray150: Scott‚Äôs vision aligns here - singing the Psalms is not about recovering an Old Testament practice, but about Christian prayer shaped by Jesus. The Psalms prepare us for and point us toward Christ.
2. Second Temple Jewish Context Matters
Wright begins with the Second Temple period (4:02) - understanding how Jews between the Testaments used the Psalms informs how early Christians adopted them.
Historical Connection: Jesus and the apostles learned to pray the Psalms in this context. They inherited a living tradition of psalm-praying, not just ancient texts.
3. Personal, Pastoral, Theological, and Liturgical Dimensions
The subtitle reveals Wright‚Äôs framework - the Psalms work on multiple levels:

Personal: Individual prayer life
Pastoral: Caring for souls through scripture
Theological: Deep doctrine embedded in poetry
Liturgical: Corporate worship practice

For Pray150: A comprehensive Psalter can‚Äôt just be hymnological - it must serve all four dimensions.
4. Specific Psalms Wright Focuses On

Psalm 90: Mortality, God‚Äôs eternity, human frailty
Psalm 102: Lament, suffering, hope
Psalm 103: Praise, God‚Äôs mercy and compassion
Psalm 8: Human dignity, creation, God‚Äôs glory
Psalm 51: Confession, repentance, renewal

Pattern: Wright doesn‚Äôt just discuss ‚Äúhappy‚Äù psalms - he includes lament (102) and penitence (51). The full emotional range is represented.
5. New Testament Scholarly Authority
N.T. Wright is one of the world‚Äôs most respected New Testament scholars. His endorsement of psalm-praying carries significant theological weight, especially for evangelicals who might dismiss psalms as ‚ÄúOld Testament law.‚Äù
Strategic Value: Wright bridges academic scholarship and congregational practice - exactly what Pray150 needs to gain credibility.

2. Integration of Indigenous Voices
The First Nations Version is used for all readings. Terry and Darlene Wildman lead original psalm songs. This isn‚Äôt tokenism - it‚Äôs theological: the Psalms speak in every culture‚Äôs voice.

7. Copyright & Contemporary Composition

Zac Hicks
Mac Meador
Kiran Young Wimberly
Terry & Darlene Wildman
Hope College Worship

For Pray150: Scott doesn‚Äôt need to write all 150 settings himself - he can curate and commission from living composers.
8. First Nations Version As Translation
This isn‚Äôt just using Native American musical style - it‚Äôs using a culturally-contextualized Bible translation (First Nations Version). The text itself is indigenous.
Research Question: What is the First Nations Version? Who created it? How does it handle Hebrew poetry? This deserves deeper study.
